Description: Small orange terracotta oil lamp in a flat ovoid shape with one end slightly pointed, flame nozzle at pointed end, with a blackend hole, and circular perforation in central disc. Handle is missing. Geometric relief decoration on central disc leads to nozzle. The base is slightly rounded with no foot. There are black inclusions from the nozzle to just above the drilled hole in the center of the lamp. There is a chipped area at the back of the lamp, probably where a handle was attached, with a small, circular indent in the center
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Spurlock Museum, University of Illinois. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

End 6th to beginning of the 7th century BC parallels from Kom el-Dikka, Alexandria (Mlynarczyk 1998, 350, Fig 23). Parallels in the British Museum dated 6th to 7th century AD (Bailey 1988, Q2203-7). Mlynarczyk, J. 1998. Terracotta mould-made lamps in Alexandria (Hellenistic to Late Roman period), in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 327-52.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KF.04) (Phase 3)
